awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Spin Physics `by design' in quantum dot molecules
awd_abstract_narration:
Non-Technical
Modern electronic devices (e.g. computer hard drives) use "spin" to store information. Other optoelectronic devices (e.g. lasers) use light to transmit information. This project investigates new materials that could integrate these two functions in a single system. We will explore the properties of coupled pairs of semiconductor quantum dots that behave like molecules with unique and tunable properties.  The results will provide the scientific foundation for building faster and more powerful computing, information transmission and information storage devices. The project will train graduate students in the conduct of research. It will also help to inspire and educate younger students by bringing hands-on scientific experiments into K-12 classrooms. 

Technical
Coupled pairs of semiconductor quantum dots are called quantum dot molecules because coherent tunneling between the individual quantum dots leads to the formation of molecular states with unique and tunable properties. This project will develop the scientific foundation for predictive design of tailored properties for individual charges confined within quantum dot molecules. To accomplish this objective, the research team is investigating specific changes in the structure, composition and electric field environment of the quantum dot molecule that they hypothesize will lead to new optoelectronic and spin properties. The team will grow designed quantum dot molecules using molecular beam epitaxy and fabricate device structures that allow application of two-dimensional electric field profiles that break the molecular symmetry. The resulting optoelectronic and spin properties will be characterized with optical spectroscopy at low temperatures and in high magnetic fields. The team will develop the computational tools necessary to accurately predict the properties of new quantum dot complexes that incorporate nontraditional materials such as GaBiAs and rare-earth nanoinclusions. Close interaction between theory and experiment will allow refinement and validation of the computational models, setting the stage for predictive engineering of solid state nanostructures with tailored properties.

por.por_cntn:
Semiconductor materials are the workhorse of modern electronics. Growth of these materials one atomic layer at a time combined with nanoscale patterning has allowed exotic combinations of materials to be developed and used in ever smaller electronic devices. Designer materials and devices have been developed with a wide range of electronic and optical properties to enable the extraordinary range and functionality of modern computing from high performance computers to tablets to smartphones. Recently, it has become clear that an unprecedented leap in computing power could be realized based on quantum processing using the quantum properties of bits to encode information, rather than traditional computer processing which treats computer bits as simple ones and zeros. Quantum processing offers the promise of greatly enhanced computing for secure information transfer, solution of hard optimization problems or ultrafast simulations for drug discovery. The race to develop quantum processing has become a worldwide race.

The work supported from this award was a collaborative effort between the University of Maryland and the University of Delaware to design, fabricate and understand new semiconductor materials with emergent properties targeted for enhanced quantum processing. Exploiting semiconductor devices for quantum processing is key towards developing scalable approaches to quantum computing that can exploit the capabilities already developed by the semiconductor industry. The semiconductor materials we considered trap charge carriers (i.e. electrons) in small regions called quantum dots. The trapped carriers act as the quantum bits (i.e. the qubits). In previous work, we showed how the spin of a qubit could be manipulated using just the applied bias on the device and a light pulse to excite the qubit, without needing an auxiliary magnetic field to control the spin. Magnets are big and hard to add to nanoscale electronic devices. Eliminating them from the device design would be a significant advance in the design of quantum devices.

In our work, we proposed to modify the quantum dot structures by growing nontraditional materials like layers of bismuth (Bi) in the middle of the gallium arsenide (GaAs) layers that separate pairs of indium arsenide (InAs) quantum dots, exploiting the properties of the Bi to enhance the control of the qubit spin trapped in the quantum dot. At the University of Maryland, we developed the computational tools needed to perform atom-scale modeling of these novel materials and devices. We demonstrated four-fold enhancement of the coupling between pairs of quantum dots that could lead to the enhanced spin manipulation. Bismuth atoms are much larger and heavier than any of the other atoms in the devices. This large mismatch leads to additional strain and significant differences in atomic electronic properties. We further showed how these differences define the emergent properties of our novel devices. We further extended our device concept by showing how the qubit spin could be fully polarized or even flipped by an applied bias across the quantum dots rather than, as is usually done, across the layers separating the quantum dots, providing a new way to manipulate the spin. Our partners at the University of Delaware developed the experimental techniques to grow these novel materials and to implement the gating to apply the desired in-plane bias. Together, these advances provide new capabilities to design devices exploiting nontraditional materials and designs for new quantum processing applications.

With support from this award, five graduate students and two undergraduate students were trained to conduct and report scientific research at the two universities. At the University of Maryland, the graduate student was further trained to mentor and lead others by guiding the undergraduate research project and the undergraduate was supported to present his research at a national meeting, giving him first-hand experience of the research process.
